channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: A tale of mistaken identity: Scholars clear up some Chaucer references
item.description: Two scholars have made new conclusions about a sermon from the late 12th century, which reframes some confusing references, made by the 14th century English poet Geoffrey Chaucer.

item.title: WNBA's got game — just check out the shoes
item.description: Nike is dropping three of its most popular basketball silhouettes just in time for the WNBA All-Star Weekend in Indianapolis — including New York Liberty star Sabrina Ionescu's Sabrina 3s.

item.title: Clergy grapple with the ethics of using AI to write sermons
item.description: How would you feel if you found out that the sermon at your church was written by artificial intelligence? What does it means when the word of God comes from a chatbot?

item.title: A federal report looks at Amtrak's efforts to improve for passengers with disabilities
item.description: For years, disabled passengers have complained about Amtrak and its poor service -- that it's too hard for them to ride the train. A new federal report looks at its efforts to get better.

item.title: Controversial nominee Emil Bove is 1 step from a job as a federal appeals court judge
item.description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is voting on the judicial nomination of Emil Bove, a top Justice Department leader at the center of controversy this year.

item.title: The effect that the rescission package could have on global health
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with Dr. Atul Gawande, previously the assistant administrator of USAID, about the effect that the rescission package could have on global health.

item.title: Paris replaces cars with bikes, closes motorways and plants thousands of trees
item.description: Over the past 20 years, the city of Paris has increasingly restricted vehicle traffic — encouraging people to walk, use public transportation or ride their bicycles.

item.title: Two fictional bands are topping the Billboard charts
item.description: NPR's Stephen Thompson reports on two new bands that are topping the Billboard charts despite being fictional K- pop groups from a new Netflix movie.

item.title: 'A Return to Self: Excursions in Exile' is part travelogue, part memoir
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Aatish Taseer about his book A Return to Self. It's part travelogue, part memoir and finds the writer wrestling with questions about immigration and cultural identity.

item.title: FEMA is at work in Texas flood zones, but private relief groups lead the way
item.description: After early criticism for being late, FEMA is getting high marks from people affected by the July 4 floods, especially in hard-hit Hunt, Texas. But locals heap even more praise on religious charities.
